title: Typographic BERLIN
content:
I’m trying to save what is yet to be saved, as I did not manage to ask this in time.

I’ve got some more days left, and wanted to ask, what not to miss in Berlin, typographically?

Any museums, exhibitions, foundries to visit? Any signage to look out for?

All tips appreciated!

 [‹ help me identify this font?](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.typophile.com/node/44928 "Go to previous forum topic") [Type Design Books ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.typophile.com/node/2843 "Go to next forum topic")
author: aszszelp

comments.content:
Well, aside from FontShop in Kreuzberg, there aren’t any foundries left in Berlin, although the city is awash in type designers!

In terms of letters, I love to visit the city’s many cemeteries. Here are a few photos – [http://www.flickr.com/photos/typeoff/sets/72157600961533746/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/typeoff/sets/72157600961533746/ "http://www.flickr.com/photos/typeoff/sets/72157600961533746/")

The Bode Museum on the Museumsinsel has lots of letters in its basement medieval collection, and also in its large coin collection. The Bauhaus-Archiv might have lettering, but I’ve not been inside it. There are a number of Soviet and East German memorials with expressionistic stone-carved letters, too. If you go up to the top of the Reichstag, and look down into one of the courtyards, you can see a large lettered installation by Hans Haake.

Near the Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz there are a series of Rosa Luxemburg quotes set as inlaid metal letters into the pavement.

Check out these older threads:  
 [Interesting typographic places in Berlin?](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34882)  
 [Specialist Art & Design Bookstores in Berlin](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.typophile.com/node/30020)  
 [Berlin](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.typophile.com/node/16903)

Not much to add. You’re too early for [TYPO](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/typoberlin.de/), and as [Ivo](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.fontwerk.com/582/1hundreddaysinsanfrancisco-noch-ein-kurzes-lebenszeichen/) is having a good time in San Francisco, no [Typo-Stammtisch](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.flickr.com/groups/typostammtisch-berlin/) at the moment either.

F

Right now, you can visit an interesting exhibition of graphic design tag-team Ott + Stein, whose [works](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/hardwig/sets/72157604791124432/) (posters, typographic logos, books) were quite formative and influential for the Berlin scene in the last 3 decades.

[Ott + Stein Grafikdesign](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905090050/http:/www.smb.museum/smb/kalender/details.php?objID=15319)  
The graphic works of Nicolaus Ott and Bernard Stein  
Retrospective exhibition at Kulturforum Potsdamer Platz, Kunstbibliothek

Matthäikirchplatz 8, S Potsdamer Platz  
Until 15 June 2008. Tue–Fri 10–18 h, Sat/Sun 11–18 h
